Planned Changes to Improve Safety
The facility has no plans at the present time to make any changes. 

Worst Case Scenario

The worst-case scenario that was considered was catastrophic release of propane from a 90,000 Gallons Tank. Using EPA RMP Comp, the calculated worst case distance to 1 psi over pressure end point for vapor cloud explosion is 0.4 miles.

RMP Comp was used as a tool to calculate distance to endpoints of 1 psi over pressure. RMP Comp assumes meteorological conditions for the worst-case scenario of atmospheric stability class F (stable atmosphere) and wind speed 1.5 meters per second (3.4 miles per hour). Ambient air temperature assumed is 25 C (77 F). TMT-equivalent model is used which assumes a yield factor of 10 percent (10%).

Alternative Release Scenario

For alternative release scenario, release from transfer hoses at the facility was considered. The total quantity of propane released was calculated as approximately 20 lbs.  The active mitigation devices were assumed to work as designed, limited the release to the contents of the hose. Using equation from Appendix C1 (EPA Offsite Consequence Analysis), the calculated distance to 1psi overpressure end point for vapor cloud explosion is 0.02 miles.

The facility has a Terminal Manager who is able to immediately respond to a serious incident and provide technical expertise to emergency response agencies as needed at the scene of the incident. AmeriGas also maintains an around the clock Emergency Communications Center (ECC), which handles all after-hours and emergency calls from around the country. The ECC has the ability to contact AmeriGas field personnel, as well as Chemtrec, on any type of incident encountered at any AmeriGas location or by AmeriGas customers.
Emergency Response Plan
The facility maintains an Emergency Action Plan (EAP). The plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire, law enforcement, and medical organizations. 
Notification of potentially affected neighbors would be coordinated through the fire department or law enforcement after consultations with site personnel. If an actual incident occurs, the plan gives guidance to employees on how to respond if it is a minor problem and easily controlled on site. 
Larger emergencies require assistance from the local emergency response organizations and employees are knowledgeable as to when that outside assistance is required.
The plans are reviewed periodically to ensure that they remain up-to-date, reflecting current activities on site and employees are trained on their responsibilities in an emergency to ensure prompt response should a situation arise. The EAP is based upon the following guidelines and standards:

1.	NPGA LP-Gas Safety Handbooks: Guidelines for Developing Plant Emergency Procedures and how to Control LP-Gas Leaks and Fires.
2.	OSHA's Occupational Safety and Health Standards for General Industry, specifically: 29 CFR 1910.38, Emergency Action Plans, 29 CFR 1910.39, Fire Prevention Plans, 29 CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals, and 29 CFR 1910.120, Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response.

At the South Heidelberg, PA terminal we handle propane that is recognized by the EPA as a regulated, flammable substance. The same properties that make propane valuable as a fuel also make it necessary to practice certain safety precautions in handling to prevent leaks, spills, and accidents. First and foremost, in our operations are the efforts undertaken to ensure employee and contractor safety while on site as well as minimize the risk exposure for the surrounding communities. It is our company policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local rules and regulations.


The AmeriGas South Heidelberg, PA terminal is bulk storage and distribution facility with propane in excess of 10, 000 lbs. The following does not apply to the facility:
	The propane is stored for use as a fuel 
	The propane is held for sale and the facility is a retail facility.
Hence the Heidelberg terminal is subject to 40 CFR Part 68 and the Environmental Plan applies to the facility.

The AmeriGas South Heidelberg terminal is a propane storage and distribution facility. The process involves receiving propane via pipeline into the propane bulk storage tanks.

The facility on average stores 459,000 gallons of propane. The propane is stored in six (6) above-ground storage tanks with a capacity of 90,000 gallons each. Each tank at 85% has 76,500 gallons of propane leaving a 15% expansion space. The facility also stores 850 gallons maximum of Ethyl Mercaptan on average in 1 (one) tank with a 1,000-gallon total capacity.
